ai_choice.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Havering - Choice

Best match.Title: Getting permission for home improvements - Havering Council
Best match.Reason: It provides information on how to clarify aspects of the works you wish to complete and details about obtaining consent for home improvements, which aligns with David's need to request permission for flat modifications.

ai_page.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Havering - Page
ai_page.body:
Getting permission for home improvements

If you carry out work without permission, you will be breaking the conditions of your lease.

Please note that the Home Ownership team will not process an application for permission if you have service charge arrears.

Leaseholders need the Council's permission (Landlord's consent) for any work they may wish to carry out that will change the structure of their home.

This includes:

  • removing or building walls or chimney breasts
  • changing doors or windows
  • putting up a conservatory or extension
  • disconnecting from a communal heating system
  • putting up a satellite aerial
  • construction of driveways
  • putting up fencing
  • installation of water meter

Permission will not be granted for any work within the loft space if the loft space is not included in your lease.

Want to carry out structural alterations/additions to your home?

You must contact the Home Ownership team for consent. You will need to include full details of the works you wish to carry out along with any specification or plan.

There is a fee for this service.

We may ask one of our inspectors to visit the property to clarify any aspect of the works you wish to complete.

Once consent has been given you may still need to:

  • apply for planning or building regulations
  • apply the rules of the statutory authorities such as gas, water and electricity companies
  • keep to any conditions we set out when giving permission

Work must be carried out properly and safely by a qualified worker. We may wish to carry out an inspection once the work is completed.

ai_feedback.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Havering - Feedback

feedback.Did the text answer your query?: Yes, it explained how to request permission for flat improvements and what procedures to follow.
feedback.Was there anything that could have been: It could be clearer about the specific steps to apply online and the expected timelines for approval.
feedback.Is there any way this text could be impr: Adding a simple, step-by-step guide or checklist would make it easier to follow and ensure I don't miss anything.

ai_issue.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Havering - Issue

text_improvements.original: Please note that the Home Ownership team will not process an application for permission if you have service charge arrears.
text_improvements.issue: This statement could be rephrased to be more user-friendly and clear about the process, reducing confusion or perceived barriers.

text_improvements.original: Permission will not be granted for any work within the loft space if the loft space is not included in your lease.
text_improvements.issue: This could be clarified with simpler language and a step-by-step explanation, making the restriction easier to understand.

text_improvements.original: Once consent has been given you may still need to: apply for planning or building regulations, apply the rules of the statutory authorities such as gas, water and electricity companies, keep to any conditions we set out when giving permission
text_improvements.issue: The list of additional steps after approval may seem overwhelming or unclear unless presented as a clear checklist or sequence.

ai_improvement.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Havering - Improvement

text_issues.Issue: This statement could be rephrased to be more user-friendly and clear about the process, reducing confusion or perceived barriers.
text_issues.original: Please note that the Home Ownership team will not process an application for permission if you have service charge arrears.
text_issues.improvement: You cannot get permission if you owe money for service charges.
text_issues.why: Simplifying the language makes the requirement clearer and more approachable, reducing potential confusion or hesitation.

text_issues.Issue: This could be clarified with simpler language and a step-by-step explanation, making the restriction easier to understand.
text_issues.original: Permission will not be granted for any work within the loft space if the loft space is not included in your lease.
text_issues.improvement: You can only get permission for work in the loft if your lease includes it.
text_issues.why: A clearer, more straightforward statement helps users easily understand the condition, reducing misinterpretations.

text_issues.Issue: The list of additional steps after approval may seem overwhelming or unclear unless presented as a clear checklist or sequence.
text_issues.original: Once consent has been given you may still need to: apply for planning or building regulations, apply the rules of the statutory authorities such as gas, water and electricity companies, keep to any conditions we set out when giving permission
text_issues.improvement:
After approval, you may need to:
- Apply for planning or building regulations
- Contact authorities like gas, water, and electricity
- Follow any conditions we gave you
text_issues.why: Breaking down complex instructions into a simple, bulleted list makes them easier to understand and follow, reducing confusion.

ai_business_case.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Havering - Business Case
ai_business_case.letter:
To: CEO  
From: Web Manager (Usability Expert)  
Subject: Recommendations for Enhancing Customer Experience and Service Efficiency

Dear [CEO Name],

Based on our recent customer persona analysis, feedback, and issue review for the online application process for flat modifications, I would like to share some targeted recommendations to improve user experience, streamline service delivery, and realize cost savings for the council.

**Positive Feedback and Appreciation**

The customer, David, found the existing information clear and helpful regarding the procedures to request permission for flat improvements. This indicates that the core content effectively informs users about the process, which is excellent. Kudos to the web team for creating a solid foundation.

**Areas for Improvement and Proposed Progress**

However, feedback also highlights several opportunities to enhance clarity and reduce user uncertainty, which can directly impact service efficiency and cost reduction:

1. **Simplify and Clarify Language**  
   - Current statements such as “Please note that the Home Ownership team will not process an application if you have service charge arrears” could be rephrased to directly state, “You cannot get permission if you owe money for service charges.”  
   - *Impact:* Clear, straightforward language reduces user confusion, decreases inbound queries, and minimizes unnecessary administrative follow-ups.

2. **Implement Step-by-Step Guides or Checklists**  
   - The process post-approval (“apply for planning, contact authorities, follow conditions”) is somewhat overwhelming. Structuring this information as a bullet-point checklist or a simple flow diagram would make adherence easier.  
   - *Impact:* Simplifies customer navigation, reduces incorrect submissions or missed steps, cuts down on staff follow-up, and accelerates approvals.

3. **Enhance the Online Application Workflow with Clear Steps**  
   - Incorporate a guided online form with progress indicators, brief explanations at each step, and confirmation notices about timelines.  
   - *Impact:* Guides users efficiently through the process, reduces errors, decreases processing time, and improves customer satisfaction.

4. **Provide Estimated Timelines and Status Updates**  
   - Currently, users like David worry about delays. Embedding expected timelines and automated updates (via SMS or email) can address this.  
   - *Impact:* Builds trust, reduces inbound inquiries about status, and allows teams to allocate resources more effectively.

5. **Develop Interactive FAQs or Help Sections**  
   - Include common questions with clear, concise answers, and ‘call to action’ buttons for next steps.  
   - *Impact:* Empowers customers to self-serve, decreases staff workload, and enhances overall efficiency.

**Conclusion**

By making these adjustments—focusing on clearer language, structured guidance, and proactive communication—we can significantly improve the customer journey. This not only enhances user satisfaction but also optimizes service workflows, leading to time savings and potential cost reductions across departments.

I recommend prioritizing these usability enhancements in our digital portal updates. I am happy to collaborate with the web team to implement these recommendations and monitor their impact over time.

Best regards,  
[Your Name]  
Web Manager (Usability Expert)
